title: Housing construction shows signs of cranking up
text:
Australia's housing construction machine is picking up, with the number of new dwelling commencements rising for the first quarter in five, driven by a pick-up in apartments and townhouses.

The 1.1 per cent lift in new housing starts to 46,315 from March's 45,796 is only a minor gain and the 21 per cent quarter-on-quarter increase in attached dwellings - every class of home other than detached houses - only takes the total back to December 2018 levels, following two quarterly losses of 20 per cent and 19 per cent.

Over the 12 months to June, total yearly housing commencements fell below 200,000 for the first time since September 2014.

Pointing up? New housing starts rose for the first quarter in five in the three months to June. Nic Walker

But the figures suggest lower borrowing costs and improved access to bank credit may be breathing life into a housing construction industry that has slowed dramatically. June's quarterly total marks a 25 per cent decline on the near-62,000 total commencements chalked up in the peak March 2016 quarter.

And while Wednesday's figures showed commencements of detached houses fell 10.6 per cent in the June quarter to 25,715, there are signs demand is picking up. An industry survey on Monday showed the pace of decline in detached housing construction was easing.
description: New dwelling commencements rose slightly in the June quarter.
